articles.headline: Strong Exports Lift U.S. Agriculture Sector
articles.snippet: The export growth is propelled by higher prices for many products, including wheat, whose prices have skyrocketed as drought and heat decimated crops in Russia.
articles.abstract: The export growth is propelled by higher prices for many products, including wheat, whose prices have skyrocketed as drought and heat decimated crops in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the broader economy falters amid signs of a weakening recovery, the nation’s agriculture sector is going strong, bolstered in part by a surge in exports, according to federal estimates of farm trade and income released on Tuesday.

articles.headline: TV News for Early Risers (or Late-to-Bedders)
articles.snippet: The new battleground for stations is the morning, with news broadcasts going on air at 4:30 a.m. or earlier.
articles.abstract: The new battleground for stations is the morning, with news broadcasts going on air at 4:30 a.m. or earlier.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last season, the big battle in television was fought over late night. This season, the battleground is shaping up to be the early morning. Very early.

articles.headline: Staff Losses and Dissent May Hurt Crisis Panel
articles.snippet: The group examining the causes of the financial crisis hopes to produce a report by Dec. 15 that will influence future policies, but squabbles and turnover are hampering its efforts.
articles.abstract: The group examining the causes of the financial crisis hopes to produce a report by Dec. 15 that will influence future policies, but squabbles and turnover are hampering its efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With less than four months left to complete its work, the group appointed by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis has been hampered by an exodus of senior employees and by internal disagreements that could hinder its ability to produce a report the entire commission could support.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Trapped Chilean Miners Forge Refuge
articles.snippet: The organization and leadership of the miners will be essential to their rescue, officials said.
articles.abstract: The organization and leadership of the miners will be essential to their rescue, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile  Mario Gómez is all too familiar with the hardships of prolonged confinement. While still in his 30s, his family said, he survived as a stowaway on a ship for 11 days, living below deck on little more than bits of chocolate and drops of water collected in a shoe  an ordeal so trying it brought him closer to God.

articles.headline: Old G.M. Being Sold for Parts
articles.snippet: Motors Liquidation Company, the home of General Motors’ shuttered plants and other unwanted assets, is gradually cleaning them up and selling them off.
articles.abstract: Motors Liquidation Company, the home of General Motors’ shuttered plants and other unwanted assets, is gradually cleaning them up and selling them off.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new General Motors appears to be thriving.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: To Win Over Users, Gadgets Have to Be Touchable
articles.snippet: Researchers say that touch screens are the start of a trend to make computers more open to human gestures.
articles.abstract: Researchers say that touch screens are the start of a trend to make computers more open to human gestures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whoever said technology was dehumanizing was wrong. On screens everywhere  cellphones, e-readers, A.T.M.’s  as Diana Ross sang, we just want to reach out and touch.

articles.headline: Wall Street Surges After Good Reports
articles.snippet: Wall Street surged out of the gate and then kept going, fueled by upbeat economic news from Australia, China and, somewhat surprisingly, American manufacturing.
articles.abstract: Wall Street surged out of the gate and then kept going, fueled by upbeat economic news from Australia, China and, somewhat surprisingly, American manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Manufacturing reports that showed growth in the United States and China helped propel stocks on Wednesday, providing an upbeat start to a new month.

articles.headline: Financial Crisis Panel Lends Sympathetic Ear to Lehman’s Ex-Chief
articles.snippet: Without federal help, Lehman was not able to wind down operations in an orderly manner, which aggravated the global crisis, the former chief executive said.
articles.abstract: Without federal help, Lehman was not able to wind down operations in an orderly manner, which aggravated the global crisis, the former chief executive said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the nearly two years since Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, its former chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., has often seemed a tragic and solitary figure, telling anyone who would listen that the investment bank could have survived if only it had had more time  and received a bailout like the government gave other Wall Street banks.

articles.headline: Sales Fell in August for Carmakers
articles.snippet: Most major automakers reported significantly lower sales last month from August 2009 when “cash for clunkers” caused a surge in demand.
articles.abstract: Most major automakers reported significantly lower sales last month from August 2009 when “cash for clunkers” caused a surge in demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The fragile recovery in new-car sales stalled in August as consumers deserted showrooms that a year ago were flush with buyers drawn by the government’s cash-for-clunkers program.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
